course_title: Dilemmas of Development: Risks of Youth

learning_outcomes.description: Consider adolescent development through a range of theoretical models and frameworks of human development.

Demonstrate some knowledge and understanding of the complex interplay between biological, cognitive and psychosocial developments in adolescence especially as they relate to behaviour and identity formation.
Consider adolescence as a rapid transitional period for young people and demonstrate some understanding of the salience of this in working with young people.
Identify how parents, families, peers, schools, communities and contemporary culture affect adolescent development and behaviour.
Identify some social, economic and cultural factors in contemporary Australia and how these create particular stresses for adolescents today.
Demonstrate some knowledge of the practices and programs in relation to working with adolescents in relation to both normative, problematic and developmental behaviours.
Better understand the subsequent dilemmas and risks young people deal with in transitioning to adulthood.

assessments.due_date:
2/04/2026 2:00 pm

You are required to take this assessment sometime during the period of 30 March to 2 April 2026.
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1: Foundations Checkpoint

Description:

This task represents an assessment of knowledge and understanding of the bio-psycho-social theoretical and empirical foundations which underpin child and adolescent difficulties. The assessment examines the core conceptual knowledge essential for effective intervention.

The aim of the Foundations Checkpoint is to:

  • Demonstrate understanding of the bio-psycho-social theoretical and empirical foundations of child and adolescent difficulties.
  • Prepare you for selecting appropriate topics, resources and literature for Assessments 2 and 3.
  • Prepare you to identify an appropriate theoretical (a framework/model that proposes an explanation for the dilemma) and empirical paper (a study that evaluated an intervention based on the theory, for your chosen dilemma) required in Assessment 3.


Your Foundations Checkpoint:

  • Is an online, non-invigilated assessment taken in Blackboard. You will be required to take the assessment during the period specified.
  • Includes 5 short answer questions based on materials provided within the task (previously unseen resources/information).
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your short answer responses in Blackboard. The task has a time limit of 60 minutes. The task will time-out at 60 minutes and any completed responses will automatically be submitted at this time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Poster - Child Behaviour or Development Issue
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 2: Poster - Child Behaviour or Development Issue

Description:

This assignment involves identifying a question about some aspect of child behaviour or development that might interest parents attending an orientation night at a local high school. There are lots of ways to come up with an appropriate question. For example:

·        Do some basic research to identify trending topics in education or psychology.

·        Reflect on your own high school journey. What challenges did your parents have about your behaviour or development?

·        Reflect of what your concerns might be if you were a parent of an adolescent today e.g., stress management, academic pressure, social dynamics, technology use.

·        Talk to a person who has regular contact with a child or adolescent (e.g., teacher, parent).

Your task is to design and prepare a poster which is suitable to be displayed at a ‘Parents’ Orientation Night’, therefore your audience are parents whose child (aged approx. 12-13 years) is commencing high school. Your poster must be written in non-technical (i.e., lay-person) language.

The list of potential questions is endless, but here are some examples:

•     How can I encourage open communication with my child while respecting their independence?

•     How can I help my child find a healthy balance of screen time for schoolwork, social media, and fun?

•     How can I encourage my child to develop good time management and study habits?

•     What strategies can I use to ensure my child gets enough quality sleep in their teenage years?

 

The aim of the assignment is to:

•     Identify an appropriate question (just one question) for parents of children commencing high school.

•     Design a poster which is interesting, informative, easy-to-read and has visual impact.

•     Prepare a poster which contains information to answer the question, provides implications for parents, and includes references and resources to help a parent navigate the sometimes- difficult period of adolescence. 


Your poster must:

•     Make a professional (and aesthetic) impression

•     Be prepared in PowerPoint A0 size

•     Have a clear heading which identifies the question your poster is addressing

•     Be divided into clearly recognisable segments or subheadings

•     Contain body text which is written in non-technical (i.e., lay-person) language

•     Contain neatly arranged graphic elements and an appropriate colour scheme

•     Provide sufficient and scientifically sound information to answer the question

•     Contain references and resources for further reading
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Research Essay - Adolescent Dilemma in Context
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 3: Research Essay - Adolescent Dilemma in Context

Topic:          Chosen by student 


Description:

The Research Essay requires you to investigate and report on a specific and relevant adolescent dilemma in a chosen context (family, school or community).


The aim of the Research Essay is to:

·          Investigate your chosen adolescent dilemma in context.

·          Critically review the theoretical and empirical literature.

·          Answer the research questions provided.

·          Use published (peer-reviewed) literature and draw clear conclusions summarising the main points of your investigation.


Your Essay must include:

Introduction (approx. 200 words).

In this section you will provide a description of your topic, that is, the adolescent dilemma and the context (e.g., you might choose to investigate suicide prevention in the school context). You will define any key terms and provide prevalence rates for this problem.

Research Questions (as appropriate for your dilemma).

Address the following questions (minor edits allowed). Covert these questions into suitable subheadings to provide a thorough analysis of the theoretical and empirical literature for your chosen dilemma (xxx) in context (yyy).

  1. What are the risks facing adolescents in relation to xxx?
  2. Does xxx differ for males/females or across ages (younger vs older adolescents)?
  3. Is xxx more pronounced in specific socioeconomic and/or cultural groups? Is it related to media, policy changes, sexuality and young people?
  4. What theory or theories have been proposed to explain xxx in adolescence?
  5. What yyy-based initiatives or prevention programs have been used based on the theory or these theories? Have these interventions or strategies been found to be effective for reducing xxx? What are the limitations and/or strengths of these interventions?
  6. What are the practical implications of the research? i.e., the take-home messages?


Conclusion (approx. 200 words). Draw logical conclusions from the literature regarding the directions for future research and practical implications for your findings.

References (as required to justify all your claims). References must be used throughout your essay and listed in APA 7th edition format.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1 - Introduction to Adolescents

This week will provide an overview of the course content and assessment requirements. We will also begin our learning journey as we examine adolescence from an historical perspective, and define adolescence within a contemporary biological, social, and cultural context.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 - Introduction to Adolescents This week will provide an overview of the course content and assessment requirements. We will also begin our learning journey as we examine adolescence from an historical perspective, and define adolescence within a contemporary biological, social, and cultural context.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2 - Early life development

This week introduces some of the major biological influences and early nurturing experiences, genes, gestation, birth, attachment theory and parenting styles.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 - Early life development This week introduces some of the major biological influences and early nurturing experiences, genes, gestation, birth, attachment theory and parenting styles.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3 - Adverse childhood experiences

This week we investigate the effects of trauma, complex trauma, adverse childhood experiences, impact on adolescent learning, and examine trauma informed classrooms.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3 - Adverse childhood experiences This week we investigate the effects of trauma, complex trauma, adverse childhood experiences, impact on adolescent learning, and examine trauma informed classrooms.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4 - Theoretical perspectives

This week introduces some of the major theoretical perspectives of adolescence, taking a particular emphasis on Bronfenbrenner's ecological framework of human development. We also examine the approach of Positive Youth Development (PYD).


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4 - Theoretical perspectives This week introduces some of the major theoretical perspectives of adolescence, taking a particular emphasis on Bronfenbrenner's ecological framework of human development. We also examine the approach of Positive Youth Development (PYD).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5 - Adolescence - biology and neurology

This week we investigate the cognitive changes that occur during adolescence, and the implications of this development on the young person. We will cover historical theories of adolescent cognitive development and the emerging neurobiological model for adolescent cognitive development.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5 - Adolescence - biology and neurology This week we investigate the cognitive changes that occur during adolescence, and the implications of this development on the young person. We will cover historical theories of adolescent cognitive development and the emerging neurobiological model for adolescent cognitive development.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6 - Adolescent mental health I

This week provides an introduction to mental health issues for adolescents. It will also discuss common disorders in the Australian context (focus on anxiety & depression) literacy.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6 - Adolescent mental health I This week provides an introduction to mental health issues for adolescents. It will also discuss common disorders in the Australian context (focus on anxiety & depression) literacy.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7 - Adolescence - identity

This week we explore the formation of identity, development of self-concept, self-esteem, and autonomy. We examine social transitions, the role of peers and social media.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7 - Adolescence - identity This week we explore the formation of identity, development of self-concept, self-esteem, and autonomy. We examine social transitions, the role of peers and social media.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8 - Adolescent engagement

This week we use theories such as motivation, feedback, goal theory and self-efficacy to investigate ways of engaging adolescents.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8 - Adolescent engagement This week we use theories such as motivation, feedback, goal theory and self-efficacy to investigate ways of engaging adolescents.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9 - Adolescent mental health II

This week continues to explore mental health issues for adolescents. It will discuss some more common mental health issues (eating disorders, self-harm, suicidality, gaming addiction, substance abuse).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9 - Adolescent mental health II This week continues to explore mental health issues for adolescents. It will discuss some more common mental health issues (eating disorders, self-harm, suicidality, gaming addiction, substance abuse).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10 - Own Topic

Work of Research Essay - Assessment 3
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10 - Own Topic Work of Research Essay - Assessment 3

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11 - School-based suicide prevention

This week we examine the problem of youth suicide and explore what schools can do and the importance of mental health literacy.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11 - School-based suicide prevention This week we examine the problem of youth suicide and explore what schools can do and the importance of mental health literacy.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12 - Adolescents at risk

This week looks at Australian Indigenous youth, youth from other cultures, and youth with disabilities.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 12 - Adolescents at risk This week looks at Australian Indigenous youth, youth from other cultures, and youth with disabilities.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13 - Review

This week will be an opportunity to review key concepts and provide a discussion forum.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 13 - Review This week will be an opportunity to review key concepts and provide a discussion forum.
